If the master branch you pushed is a child of the local branch, then anything in the log and hence in the content of each commit within the local branch will be accessible via the master. However, if the reverse is true, then you don't need to worry, local branch is tracking the latest commit of master and anything you code on local branch will not be seen on master branch unless merged into it. You need to think of Git as taking snapshots of everything inside a Git repo locally at a particular point in time, then tracks this snapshot and makes the next one. It is like taking a series of pictures of a moving object without adding each time new objects to the storage. That is why it is so lightweight and switching branches takes microseconds.
